messages.text: (X is an array of 64x2MIL)

What do you mean by "`S` is not SPD" here?
Not symmetric? Slightly negative eigenvalues? Cholesky factorization fails?

Since `X` is `64 x 2_000_000`, each coefficient in `S` is a sum with 2 million terms --> you're indeed likely to have some rounding errors, especially if the range of non-zero coeffs in `X` is large.

The transformation `S = (S + S') * 0.5` will only addresses symmetry, not negative eigenvalues.

messages.text: Cholesky factorization fails
althou no negative eigenvalues
the smallest is `6.810845f9`
The obvious first: have you tried `F = cholesky(Symmetric(S))`? It will ensure the input to `cholesky` is structurally symmetric.

messages.text:
More generally, Cholesky requires PD matrices. Here `S` is PD if and only if `X` has full row rank, which is likely to be the case since it has 2M columns.
I would check the numerical range of coefficients in `S`:
```extrema(S)```
If you have very small/large coefficients, and/or the ratio `max/min` is large, then there's a good chance you'll get numerical issues in the factorization itself (e.g. numerically small pivots).
One way to get rid of that is to re-scale `X` , so that `S` is better-scaled. For instance, ensure that the norm of each row/column in `X` is closed to one.

messages.text: Working on raw f64 data `isposdef(S)` was true

In any case, your `S` looks badly conditioned: the largest element is ~250_000 larger than the smallest one. That's only about ~100x the machine precision for Float32.
So it's highly likely the Cholesky factorization will have a lot of rounding errors.

One option is always to add some positive term to the diagonal, e.g., to factorize `S + zI` for a well-chosen `z` .
`z` should be small enough to not perturb the system too much, but large enough to actually make the factorization more stable.

The A \ b operator finds the minimum-norm solution if the matrix is rectangular, but tries to solve the system as-is when A is square - and fails if it is singular. How to always get the min-norm solution, even for square matrix?

I have some complex code involving compound types with sparse matrices in them. To make the code a bit more cleaner and readable, I introduced these redefinitions, which allow for Matlab-like behaviour, allowing sparse right-hand sides. (I know memory is not an issue)
```ldiv!(A::Factorization, B::AbstractSparseMatrix) = ldiv!(A, Matrix(B))
ldiv!(A::Factorization, B::AbstractSparseVector) = ldiv!(A, Vector(B))
rdiv!(A::AbstractSparseMatrix, B::Factorization) = rdiv!(Matrix(A), B)
rdiv!(A::AbstractSparseVector, B::Factorization) = rdiv!(Vector(A), B)
ldiv!(A::AbstractMatrix, B::AbstractSparseMatrix) = ldiv!(A, Matrix(B))
ldiv!(A::AbstractMatrix, B::AbstractSparseVector) = ldiv!(A, Vector(B))
rdiv!(A::AbstractSparseMatrix, B::AbstractMatrix) = rdiv!(Matrix(A), B)
rdiv!(A::AbstractSparseVector, B::AbstractMatrix) = rdiv!(Vector(A), B)```
However, I get this warning: An imported function has been extended without using module defined typed arguments. Any clues on how to resolve this?

elements.text: I have some complex code involving compound types with sparse matrices in them. To make the code a bit more cleaner and readable, I introduced these redefinitions, which allow for Matlab-like behaviour, allowing sparse right-hand sides. (I know memory is not an issue)

ldiv!(A::Factorization, B::AbstractSparseMatrix) = ldiv!(A, Matrix(B))
ldiv!(A::Factorization, B::AbstractSparseVector) = ldiv!(A, Vector(B))
rdiv!(A::AbstractSparseMatrix, B::Factorization) = rdiv!(Matrix(A), B)
rdiv!(A::AbstractSparseVector, B::Factorization) = rdiv!(Vector(A), B)
ldiv!(A::AbstractMatrix, B::AbstractSparseMatrix) = ldiv!(A, Matrix(B))
ldiv!(A::AbstractMatrix, B::AbstractSparseVector) = ldiv!(A, Vector(B))
rdiv!(A::AbstractSparseMatrix, B::AbstractMatrix) = rdiv!(Matrix(A), B)
rdiv!(A::AbstractSparseVector, B::AbstractMatrix) = rdiv!(Vector(A), B)
However, I get this warning: An imported function has been extended without using module defined typed arguments. Any clues on how to resolve this?

hi guys, I am not sure whether this is the right place to ask but maybe worth a try:
I am using the package LowRankApprox.jl and I am trying to access a `U::LowRankMatrix` , using indices written in a vector, say  `i = [1,2,3,4]`  . Weirdly, I am getting the following error message when I try to access those indices by doing `U[i,i]`  :

```debug> U[[1,2,3,4],[1,2,3,4]]
ERROR: setindex! not defined for LowRankApprox.LowRankMatrix{Float64}
Stacktrace:
 [1] error(::String, ::Type{T} where T) at ./error.jl:42
 [2] error_if_canonical_setindex(::IndexCartesian, ::LowRankApprox.LowRankMatrix{Float64}, ::Int64, ::Int64) at ./abstractarray.jl:1163
 [3] setindex! at ./abstractarray.jl:1152 [inlined]
 [4] _setindex! at ./abstractarray.jl:1183 [inlined]
 [5] setindex! at ./abstractarray.jl:1153 [inlined]
 [6] macro expansion at ./multidimensional.jl:772 [inlined]
 [7] macro expansion at ./cartesian.jl:64 [inlined]
 [8] macro expansion at ./multidimensional.jl:767 [inlined]
 [9] _unsafe_getindex! at ./multidimensional.jl:762 [inlined]
 [10] _unsafe_getindex(::IndexCartesian, ::LowRankApprox.LowRankMatrix{Float64}, ::Array{Int64,1}, ::Array{Int64,1}) at ./multidimensional.jl:757
 [11] _getindex at ./multidimensional.jl:743 [inlined]
 [12] getindex(::LowRankApprox.LowRankMatrix{Float64}, ::Array{Int64,1}, ::Array{Int64,1}) at ./abstractarray.jl:1060
 [13] top-level scope at none:1```
anyone here has a tip? thanks in advance :)

messages.text:
I'd like to tap the Julia hive-mind about something that might not be strictly related to Julia. If I have two square N x N matrices of rank M < N, is there a way to do `schur(A, B)` more efficiently, perhaps working it out first on the M x M full-rank subspaces and then inflating the result to NxN somehow?
Since `schur` is O(N^3) the benefit could be substantial...

Since
is O(N^3) the benefit could be substantial...

messages.text: Do you know the rank? You can use ARPACK for the generalized eigenvalue problem but it can be tricky for reduced rank matrices

elements.text: Do you know the rank? You can use ARPACK for the generalized eigenvalue problem but it can be tricky for reduced rank matrices

messages.text: Yes, M is known, and typically much smaller than N. But I want to avoid using eigen! because of numerical stability issues. I actually did it the way you suggest first, but the numerical noise in some cases was a problem because of ill-conditioning (several eigenvectors almost parallel). The schur step of eigen, however, should not be affected by ill-conditioning, hence my question. But I'm struggling to understand how to make it work.

messages.text: By not good with threading, I was referring to small sizes arrays. BLIS does fine asymptotically, but both OpenBLAS and BLIS seem a fair bit behind MKL asymptotically on my Skylake-X desktops. Over the size ranges I tested, Octavian was on par with BLIS and OpenBLAS there (after tuning it for those specific marchines); I haven't been able to match MKL for large matrices with Octavian's current approach.

elements.text: By not good with threading, I was referring to small sizes arrays. BLIS does fine asymptotically, but both OpenBLAS and BLIS seem a fair bit behind MKL asymptotically on my Skylake-X desktops. Over the size ranges I tested, Octavian was on par with BLIS and OpenBLAS there (after tuning it for those specific marchines); I haven't been able to match MKL for large matrices with Octavian's current approach.

messages.text: For small matrices, you need to do some combination of not oversubscribing threads, and changing your blocking behavior to get good utilization.

I just browsed <https://raw.githubusercontent.com/flame/libflame/master/docs/libflame/libflame.pdf> and it looks like the coverage of LAPACK functionality is incomplete, e.g. there is no Schur factorization. It also doesn’t look like there are DnQ versions of the Hermitian eigensolver and SVD solver. It would be interesting to compare the bi- and tridiagonal  reduction functions to MKL, though. Intel’s version are super fast compared to vanilla LAPACK and it is often the reduction is often bottleneck for large problems.

messages.text: Basic question: Do preconditioners improve the accuracy of the ultimate solution (and defeat the accuracy floor set by the condition number of the original system), or do they just allow you to get to the solution faster (but not more accurately)?

elements.text: Basic question: Do preconditioners improve the accuracy of the ultimate solution (and defeat the accuracy floor set by the condition number of the original system), or do they just allow you to get to the solution faster (but not more accurately)?

messages.text: The latter, unless you have a clever way of computing the preconditioned residual without first computing the residual then precondition it

messages.text:
Consider the complex square matrix `C` and the real square matrix `R` , with equal sizes.

I want to calculate `C⁻¹ R C⁻¹*` .

I am currently doing
```result = let
  C⁻¹ = inv(C)
  C⁻¹ * R * conj(C⁻¹)
end```
I wonder if you guys know any mathematical trick or special BLAS function that can optimise this operation, because I am out of ideas!

messages.text: I can't seem to be able to reach the relevant thread anymore, but I think there was interest in lazy outer products/rank-1 operators/Kronecker products of a vector and an adjoint/transpose vector. Besides the obvious `Kronecker.jl`, there's now also `LinearMaps.jl` at version 3.3 that allows to have `u⊗v'`  and provides optimal "matrix"-vector multiplication via `(u⊗v')*x = u*(v'x)`  and without internal reshaping. Check it out!

messages.text: The difference is that it's easier to write completely invalid and incorrect code when you use explicit ranges. If you iterate over the axes of the array, it's much safer. Often you don't even need to use `@inbounds` if you use `axes` and only write to the corresponding array index because the compiler can prove that the access is inbounds.

messages.text: No, it's on 0.12

This doesn't normally matter, but I'd advise you use `oneunit` here instead of `one` if this is to work with arbitrary number types. `one(T)` gives the multiplicative identity, whereas `oneunit(T)` gives the addative unit.
